steps.title: Sift the teff flour into a mixing bowl.
steps.content: Sift the teff flour into a mixing bowl. Add the warm water and salt. Mix to combine.

steps.title: If using a fermentation starter, add this now.
steps.content: If using a fermentation starter, add this now. Mix.

steps.title: Put the batter aside for 12 hours in a warm spot.
steps.content: Put the batter aside for 12 hours in a warm spot. Cover the bowl with a clean tea towel.

steps.title: Prepare the frying pan.
steps.content: Prepare the frying pan. Heat a pan until hot. Add just enough oil to coat the pan with, not too much. Tilt the pan to help the oil run from side to side and cover the whole pan base.

steps.title: Ladle the batter into the pan.
steps.content: Ladle the batter into the pan. Do this in a spiral motion, starting in the center, then working the spiral outward to fill the whole frying pan. Work on adding about as much batter as for a crepe, maybe a smidgen more.

steps.title: Cook.
steps.content: Cook. When you see holes appearing on top of the injera, it's ready to be removed. It will also lift away from the edges of the plan and appear golden brown.

steps.title: Repeat for the remaining batter until you have made several injera.
steps.content: Repeat for the remaining batter until you have made several injera.

steps.title: Serve warm or cold.
steps.content: Serve warm or cold. In Ethiopia, where it originated, Injera is never served warm.
